Award.AwardTitle: 2015 Mixed Integer Programming Workshop; Chicago, Illinois; June 1-4, 2015

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Mixed Integer Programming Workshop is an annual workshop that highlights the state of the art in discrete and continuous optimization, with a primary focus being to showcase more junior researchers. Another goal of the workshop is to enable collaborations and scientific exchanges between leading researchers and graduate students, thus promoting the progress of basic science.

Specifically, this project will provide travel support for 10 student poster presenters, providing them the opportunity to network with the world's top researchers in a student poster session, as well as during the invited talks, which are presented in a single track format with plenty of opportunity for interaction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2015 Mixed Integer Programming (MIP) Workshop was hosted by the University of Chicago on  June 1-4th in downtown Chicago. Approximately 100 attendees attended the 24 talks by world-renown researchers in addition to 20 poster presentations by Ph. D. students and postdoctoral fellows. The MIP workshop is designed to encourage participation of junior researchers in integer programming and related areas. In order to allow for broader participation, efforts are made to keep the cost of attendance low. This was made possible this year thanks to the generous support of the NSF, six universities, and six private companies.  The NSF’s contribution provided travel support of $500 each to a diverse group of nine Ph.D. students in order to present posters of their research on integer programming. As a result of other contributions, travel support was offered to all students who requested it. Thanks to this support, many students were given a valuable opportunity to present their work and solicit feedback from academic and industry leaders. 

 

Feedback solicited from the students suggests that this experience made a positive impact on their research careers and that their participation may not have been possible without the travel award. This is particularly relevant to under represented students, as three of the nine awardees are female students.
